search_result.title: Michigan woman's insurance claim upended by amusement park ...
search_result.text:
Private eye Chris Charow has seen hundreds of instances of exaggerated injuries, faked injuries and outright fraud that contribute to Michigan's highest-in-the-nation auto insurance rates.

He photographs people who pretend to slowly limp across parking lots on their way to medical exams for no-fault insurance benefits.

Hours later, Charow, 47, will spy these same individuals appearing healthy and injury-free as they stroll supermarkets or move around their driveway at home. And the visual props that they pulled out for the doctor's office — walkers, canes, cervical collars — have disappeared.

He also has staked out physical therapy clinics and seen patients walk in and quickly exit only a few minutes later. Yet the clinics billed insurance for treatments that supposedly lasted much longer.

Lower your auto insurance costs: Find the best car insurance of 2023

Charow works as a private investigator with Commerce Township-based Jane Doe Investigations. It is one of more than a dozen investigation firms across Michigan that insurance companies hire to catch suspected no-fault fraudsters in the act.

“We’re out there to just get the truth," said Jane Doe's CEO Jane Boudreau. "People do get hurt in accidents. But people take advantage of it, and that’s the unfortunate part.”

Fraudulent claims contribute to the high price of auto insurance in Michigan because insurance companies pass along the cost of these claims to consumers in the form of higher premiums.

It is estimated that one out of 10 no-fault insurance claims in Michigan is fraudulent, said Dyck Van Koevering, general counsel for the Insurance Alliance of Michigan, an insurance industry group.

There have been no recent studies concerning the total amount of auto insurance-related fraud in the state. However, the Insurance Alliance has said that no-fault fraud and abuse are likely costing the average Michigan family hundreds of dollars a year in additional insurance premiums.

"We think fraud is a serious problem in Michigan," Van Koevering said. "Rates are a function of losses, and to the extent that fraud increases losses, it inflates the premium that is paid by the next guy.”

Michigan is considered a lucrative environment for auto insurance fraud as the only state in the nation requiring motorists to buy potentially unlimited medical benefits as part of their insurance.

Michigan also has lacked a dedicated, statewide auto insurance watchdog. Even though critics, as well as defenders, of no-fault have voiced support for a fraud authority, past proposals to establish one were often tucked into controversial legislation for overhauling the entire insurance system.

In September, Gov. Rick Snyder signed an executive order to set up an Anti-Fraud Unit within the Department of Insurance and Financial Services. The four-person unit is tasked with investigating insurance and financial-sector fraud.

“Fraud in the system drives up the cost of insurance for all Michiganders, and we need to do everything we can to eradicate it,” the governor said at the time.

Hire a PI

No-fault fraud typically takes the form of unnecessary medical expenses and dishonest claims for the system's unique benefits, such as lost wages and the opportunity for relatives or friends of accident victims to earn $14 an hour or more providing in-home "attendant care." An extra $20 per day is also available for doing the injured person's household chores.

Private investigators sometimes covertly trail these caregivers if an insurance company suspects that not all of the attendant care and chores that are billed are actually being done.

Read more:

Free Press report: Why does auto insurance in Detroit cost so much?

Detroit car insurance: Why Cleveland has it way cheaper

Ohio drivers pay less, get less for auto insurance than in Michigan

Although many insurers operate their own in-house special investigation units, they also contract with private firms such as Jane Doe Investigations, Sherlock Investigations in Clinton Township and Superior Investigative Services in Milford for specialized work that can include daylong stakeouts or following someone with hidden cameras.

Investigation firms generally cost between $60 and $100 an hour, although smaller operations may charge less.

When a person is caught in a potential no-fault fraud, insurance companies may attempt to cut off his or her benefits or compel them into a settlement. Insurers can also refer cases to local prosecutors as insurance fraud is a felony in Michigan punishable by up to four years in prison and $50,000 in fines.

But insurance companies seldom pursue individual-level fraud because the cases are generally viewed as too small and not worth the time or money to pursue, according to attorneys who represent insurers.

Insurers prefer to instead go after medical clinics that they suspect are operating large-scale no-fault patient mills.

Nevertheless, no-fault fraud at the individual level can result in bills to insurance totaling tens of thousands of dollars per claim.

Caught at the amusement park

The Free Press, in a review of auto accident-related lawsuits in Wayne County Circuit Court, found numerous no-fault claims that were upended by private investigators and undercover surveillance.

In one case, a 34-year-old Sterling Heights woman claimed that she needed eight hours a day of insurance-paid attendant care, provided by her out-of-work brother-in-law, for devastating injuries from her car accident. The brother-in-law supposedly helped her get dressed, get in and out of the shower and even with the toilet, according to court documents.

The woman claimed that she couldn't walk more than 20 or 25 minutes without pain, and for enjoyment could only sit in her backyard and drink coffee or stay inside and watch TV.

Yet only weeks before her August 2015 deposition, an undercover investigator with Lexington-based Quest Research Group caught the woman traveling with a group to the Michigan's Adventure theme park in Muskegon.

She was photographed walking around the park for nine hours without any assistance and at times pushed a stroller. The investigator took video of her on the park's log ride, waving a hand in the air and bracing for the final plunge, court documents say.

She also went on the Sea Dragon ride and the Corkscrew roller coaster, infamous for its "dizzying speeds and endless loops that will turn you inside out," according to description on the park's website.

The undercover video was devastating to the woman's lawsuit, which had sought more than $25,000 in no-fault benefits from Safeco Insurance Co.

“It is impossible to believe that (she) was able to walk about an amusement park and ride roller coasters for nine hours, but just days later she was so injured that she needed help getting in and out of the shower and with toileting and getting dressed,” Michael Martinico, an attorney representing Safeco, wrote in court documents.

The woman later signed an affidavit saying that she never lied and that the surveillance video couldn't show whether or not she was in pain.

Her lawsuit against the insurance company was ultimately settled for $6,709, with Safeco paying some medical bills but not the brother-in-law's attendant care services, court records show.

'People take advantage'

Boudreau, the founder of Jane Doe Investigations, is a former Oakland County Sheriff's sergeant and many of her investigators also have law enforcement backgrounds.

Insurance companies generally don't call her firm until they suspect something fishy with a claim. About 95 percent of all the claims that Boudreau's firm investigates turn out to be fraudulent or highly questionable, she said.

“We may find someone who maybe did break their leg, but now they’re healed, and now they are exaggerating it," Boudreau said. "When you’re better, you are not supposed to be taking free money.”

The firm also investigates suspected workers' compensation fraud or abuse of the Family and Medical Leave Act.

"We had a case with a police officer — not in Oakland County — who was in an accident and was not transported to a hospital, but broke his foot and went on his own" to the hospital, she said.

"We followed that person out of state on vacation, even had to partner with another investigative firm, and the person is supposed to be in a brace all the time and allegedly can't dress himself ... and we (caught) him at a Michigan State game, on his leg, standing, partying for hours before the game — no brace, he was fine," she said.

In a particularly egregious case, the firm investigated a mixed-martial arts fighter who claimed that he needed attendant care and suffered lasting injuries from an auto accident.

However, the MMA fighter started posting on social media about his training regimen and urged his friends to attend his upcoming cage fight in Traverse City. A Jane Doe investigator drove up to the fight and recorded the man's dramatic first-round loss.

The fight video ultimately doomed the man's insurance claims, according to Boudreau.

"I know he was asking for over $1 million," she said. "He ended up with an under $5,000 settlement; think about the money that that saved."

Going undercover

Charow, 47, has been a private investigator since the 1990s. He has staked out countless houses, apartment buildings and businesses in all sorts of neighborhoods across metro Detroit.

"In the past 20 years, I've stared down the barrel of a gun six times and been almost carjacked once," he said.

He learned the basics of investigations from a long-retired Detroit Police narcotics officer.

"He showed me how to do it old-school," he said. "These were guys that had a notepad and a Polaroid camera."

The subjects of Charow's investigations almost never realize that they are being watched or followed. When someone does notice his presence, it's usually nosy neighbors or people who wrongly assume he is there to snoop on them.

He arrives at surveillance sites with a high-zoom video camera and a readiness for anything, from 12-hour marathon stakeouts to high-speed car chases. Most car chases happen not because Charow gets spotted by the person he is watching — what PIs call getting "burned" — but because subjects of investigations can sometimes be crazy drivers.

The worst driver he ever encountered was a woman with three children in her car who darted in and out of highway traffic going 95 mph.

"I did end up having to let her go because I wasn't going to kill somebody that day," he said. "And our clients understand that, too."

Charow said his job isn't about "shredding people apart" or putting any negative spin on real injuries. Investigators like himself are paid the same regardless of what they uncover or don't uncover, he said.

"Our job is not to catch them. It is to document the truth," Charow said.

Caught driving

In another no-fault case, undercover surveillance caught a 37-year-old Madison Heights woman driving an SUV on the same day that she was a passenger in a Troy-based medical transportation company's vehicle that drove her to and from a physical therapy appointment, according to court documents.

No-fault insurance only pays for medical transportation if a patient is too injured or disabled to drive on their own.

For each round-trip, the transportation firm billed $85 to the woman's insurer, Great Lakes Casualty Insurance Co, court documents show. The total billings between January and August 2015 came to $7,560.

But after the surveillance video emerged in court, the transportation company did not get its bills paid. The court documents don't say whether the surveillance was done by an in-house insurance company investigator or a hired firm.

Unmanned cameras

Superior Investigative Services in Milford used private investigators as well as unmanned 24-hour cameras to show that a 61-year-old woman who claimed to provide in-home attendant care for a Detroit car crash victim never showed up to the home on some days when no-fault insurance was billed.

Superior's investigator staked out the crash victim's address in November 2016 and didn't spot the caregiver coming or going over two days, according to court documents filed on behalf of Farmers Insurance.

However, the caregiver — who said she was paid $20 per hour — signed paperwork claiming to have worked both days in the home.

Later, Superior set up the unmanned pedestal cameras for three days in late January and early February 2017 outside the crash victim's house and the caregiver's house, both in Detroit. The cameras never found the caregiver visiting the patient, court documents say.

The pedestal cameras were brought out again at the end of February. That happened after the crash victim's attorney allegedly emailed Farmers Insurance's attorney on Feb. 27 with attendant care paperwork for the full month — even showing services supposedly provided in the future on Feb. 28.

The investigators put up the 24-hour cameras at both residences that day to see what would happen. Once again, the caregiver never showed, according to Farmers Insurance.

"The pedestal camera systems run 24 hours per day for each day uninterrupted so that an individual cannot later claim they showed up somewhere 'after' the surveillance man (or woman) left the area — or had arrived before," wrote attorney Kristen Kosciolek, representing Farmers Insurance. "The system is a foolproof way of finding out if someone is telling the truth or not."

Surveillance fails

But surveillance efforts sometimes do fail.

That is what appears to have happened when Great Lakes Casualty brought in an undercover investigator two years ago to see whether a 33-year-old woman in Sterling Heights was still injured from an accident that occurred 17 months earlier.

The investigator — whose identity isn't disclosed in court filings — recorded footage of a person whom he or she thought was the accident victim outside an apartment complex carrying a young child while talking on a cellphone. At one point the person in the video runs across the complex's parking lot.

Months later, the insurance claimant testified that she was still too injured to do household chores and couldn't pick up her young daughter.

The insurance company's lawyers then presented the surveillance video and accused the woman of fraud.

But the woman's attorney pointed out a problem. The video actually showed the woman's neighbor in the parking lot with a child — not her.

The judge denied the insurance company's motion to end the lawsuit. The final insurance settlement last year wasn't disclosed.

"Insurance companies are attempting to engage in surveillance of claimants to avoid having to pay benefits," said Ali Ajrouch, a senior attorney with the Law Offices of Joumana Kayrouz, which represented the woman. "On occasion, their investigators end up with footage of persons who are not the actual claimant. This is not the first time and probably not the last time that we will encounter such a situation."

A Great Lakes Casualty representative did not return a message seeking comment.

Time to get aggressive?

Charow, the private investigator, said he believes that more aggressive prosecution of insurance fraudsters could have a strong deterrent effect.

Right now, many individuals who are caught in schemes go unpunished. The worst that generally happens to them is their insurance benefits get cut off and they have to take settlements, he said.

"What happens when you catch somebody? They get a big settlement check and there are no criminal charges filed," Charow said. "Start putting some penalties on this and the fraud will slow down. That's how we're going to get it to be an affordable, honest system."

Contact JC Reindl: 313-222-6631 or jcreindl@freepress.com. Follow him on Twitter @JCReindl.

search_result.title: NJ disasters from the 20th century featured in Morristown exhibit
search_result.text:
Major fires, explosions, mine accidents and other North Jersey disasters of the 20th century will be brought back to life through a Morris County Historical Society exhibit at its Morristown museum.

The photo-driven exhibit takes a look at 12 fires, mine accidents, explosions, aircraft crashes and disasters from 1910 to 1989. Titled "Up in Smoke: Northern New Jersey’s Worst Man-Made Disasters," the exhibit will be on display through April 26, 2020, at Acorn Hall on Morris Avenue in Morristown.

With the exhibit open, we combed through old newspapers to look back at six significant 20th-century disasters across Bergen, Passaic and Morris counties.

Meadowlands explosion: 1917

The Kingsland explosion took place during World War I at the munitions factory in Lyndhurst on Jan. 11, 1917. The fire at the sprawling munitions plant in the Meadowlands sent hundreds fleeing from their homes under a rain of 3-inch shells.

The disaster started with an electrical fire in a shell cleaning department at the Canadian Car and Foundry munitions plant, The Record reported. It ended after about four hours and the destruction of 500,000 high explosive shells, according to Lyndhurst Historical Society records.

Starting at about 3:45 p.m., the fire launched shells half a mile into Kingsland and neighboring towns in southern Bergen County. Shells tore through roofs and cars, narrowly missing civilians.

“The first word to reach Hackensack was that the extensive plant had been blown up and hundreds had been killed,” The Record reported on Jan. 12, 1917.

The building was leveled. However, none of the roughly 1,700 men working on a $133 million munitions order for the Russians during World War I was killed, The Record reported.

Switchboard operator Theresa McNamara stayed during the fire, plugged into dozens of buildings and succinctly told workers to “get out or go up,” according to records kept by the Lyndhurst Historical Society, which dedicated a small park on Clay Avenue in her honor.

“Not until a shell crashed through the building and barely missed her did she realize her danger,” The Record reported.

The fire and explosions caused an estimated $10 million in damage, the paper said.

Some fleeing workers were hospitalized after trudging through the marshes to Jersey City on a night when temperatures hit zero. Others attempted to swim up Berry’s Creek and the Hackensack River and were hospitalized with hypothermia.

Morningstar-Paisley explosion:Hawthorne remembers deadly plant explosion 50 years later

Modern-day disaster:Cold, wind, ice, lack of water among hurdles for firefighters who knocked down Marcal fire

Officials determined early on that the fire was the result of a snapped electrical wire in a room filled with flammable solvents and soaked rags, The Record reported.

Federal officials nonetheless blamed German sabotage for the explosion and a similar 1916 incident in Jersey City called the Black Tom explosion. In 1930, a joint commission found evidence for their claims insufficient.

The New York Times later reported that a former German spy admitted planning the Black Tom incident but took no credit for the Kingsland fire. The commission reopened the case and ordered the German government to pay $50 to compensate the Kingsland and Black Tom victims.

Paterson fireworks blaze: 1901

A fireworks explosion in downtown Paterson on June 21, 1901, sparked one of the state’s most devastating fires. Starting in a candy store in the bottom of a five-story tenement at 440 Main St., the fire killed 17 people and cremated an entire city block.

“A volcano in action could not have wrought more ruin and desolation,” The (Paterson) News reported.

The fire started around noon in Abraham Rittenberg’s candy store, when his son was handling a package of large firecrackers. One exploded, setting off a chain reaction. The boy escaped, and several other boxes of fireworks were moved across the street, The News reported. The devastation nonetheless flowed through the series of flats owned by William Walker.

“Every occupant of the entire block lost everything they had in this world except the clothes they had on their backs,” The News reported.

One resident was saved when she jumped from a window into a net held tight below, The News reported that day. Another died attempting to save her bedridden husband. The south end of the adjacent tenement collapsed, pinning down a man, who was pulled out by the gathering crowd.

Rittenberg was criticized for bringing dynamite torpedoes to the neighborhood. But while some were found in a nearby basement, fire officials confirmed that all Rittenberg had in his shop were roman candles, firecrackers and other small works, according to newspaper reports.

Rittenberg’s two children and mother-in-law both died in the fire. He was found not criminally liable for the 17 deaths but was later sued by Isaiah Bamber, who lost his wife and 6-month-old baby, Bertram, in the fire, and was ordered to pay $2,000 in damages.

Eight months later, on Feb. 9, 1902, the city was struck by an even more massive fire. Though no one died in the blaze, it destroyed more than 450 buildings across 26 blocks of the city’s business center, causing an estimated $10 million in damage.

Palisades Amusement Park fire: 1944

A roller coaster ride gone wrong at Palisades Amusement Park on Aug. 13, 1944, sparked a fire that consumed dozens of attractions, ended the park’s season and injured 150 people.

The fire started at about 2 p.m. that Sunday when a wooden car on the then-ubiquitous Virginia Reel spinning roller coaster allegedly caught fire.

“Witnesses said that within 10 seconds the slanting ride was a mass of flames," The Record reported.

Exhibit:Visit Palisades Amusement Park once again — in miniature — at Mahwah Museum

Among the eight critically injured in the blaze were four children. Their wooden car caught fire just as it began its first 50-foot descent before disappearing into a tunnel. Five soldiers and a girl who helped rescue the four children and two women from the car were badly burned, The Record reported.

The fire spread to the fun house, the merry-go-round and some concessions in the park, which once sprawled across the border between Cliffside Park and Fort Lee.

At the time, the park’s famed pool, as big as three city blocks and filled with 500,000 gallons of salt water pumped from the Hudson River, was populated with 4,000 people. Despite the chaos, they evacuated in an orderly way, The Record reported. There was no panic.

Meanwhile, 89 cars were destroyed in the parking lot across the street. Fifty more were badly burned. Their tires were scorched off.

Local officials determined the fire was likely caused by a short circuit near a collection of greasy rags used to clean the Virginia Reel’s tracks. In total, 14 fire departments responded to quell the blaze, which caused $1 million in damage.

The amusement park fire was one of the most devastating in tri-state history, but it wasn’t the only one that weekend. The previous day, most of Luna Park on Coney Island was consumed by fire. Unlike Palisades Amusement Park, which reopened the following year and operated through the 1971 season, Luna Park never opened again.

Hercules powder blasts: 1940

A munitions plant owned by DuPont spinoff Hercules Company in Roxbury was the site of one of the state’s most far-reaching disasters.

On Sept. 12, 1940, a series of explosions at the fenced 1,200-acre site, now off Route 80, destroyed more than 20 buildings, killed 51 people and injured more than 200 others. Fueled by nearly 297,000 pounds of smokeless gunpowder, the blasts registered on a Fordham University seismograph 45 miles away, according an Associated Press report.

“The only thing in the plant which appeared intact was a large boiler,” the AP reported a commercial transport pilot as saying.

The Hercules facility first opened in 1871 to make dynamite for the area’s once-thriving iron industry. Two explosions in 1934 killed six workers, but the 1940 incident was the most severe to hit the massive complex.

The hospital had to stage triage on its front lawn and deliver patients to Morristown and even as far as Newark for medical care, according to newspaper reports.

The Associated Press reported that the blasts broke windows in homes as far away as the shores of Lake Hopatcong. Pictures were knocked off walls in Poughkeepsie, New York, and damage was reported in Middletown, New York, 52 miles away, The Record reported.

The explosions started with a fire in the plant’s solvent-recovery building. Company officials did not suspect sabotage, but that did not stop some local politicians from showing up the next day to comb for evidence, The Record reported.

The plant reopened in April 1941 and continued to operate through 1996. At least a half-dozen other explosions occurred in the duration, killing more than 15 people. The last, in 1994, involved 500 pounds of nitroglycerin and injured four workers.

Roxbury Township has a plaque in the Memorial Garden at Horseshoe Lake Park with the names of the blasts’ 51 victims and many others who died at the plant.

Lake Denmark lightning strike: 1926

Two days after a thunderstorm rolled through Rockaway Township on July 10, 1926, the booms continued at the Lake Denmark ammunition depot

A lightning strike during the storm set fire to the naval depot, triggering 600,000 tons of explosives. Steel fragments rained as 12- and 14-inch shells burst within reach of the Army’s also-impressive Picatinny Arsenal.

The debris was launched more than 20 miles away. Homes in Mountain Lakes, Butler and Morristown were damaged.

In the immediate vicinity, holes 30 feet deep and 100 feet wide were left in the dense rock where two storehouses once stood.

“Great trees lie stripped of bark and foliage in the 500-acre naval reservation, some uprooted, some cut down by shell fragments, but all with their tops pointing away from the blasts,” The Associated Press reported.

Four towns suffered massive damage from the blasts. In Mount Hope, more than 100 miners’ cottages were either completely or partially destroyed, according to The Associated Press. Nearly 200 structures were leveled, leaving 800 homeless.

The disaster killed 21 people, injured about 300 more and created $47 million in damage, according to newspaper accounts. Nearly everything within a half-mile was leveled, and the epicenter smoldered for days.

“The scene was reminiscent of a battlefield the day after the shock troops of any enemy had wrought their bloody will and withdrawn to other sectors,” The Associated Press reported on July 12.

Government officials chalked up the disaster to natural causes. A copper ground wire had been erected to protect the single-story brick building from a direct lightning hit, according to newspaper reports. A bolt nonetheless ripped through the tar and gravel roof, the precaution having apparently been insufficient.

Midvale train crash: 1904

A series of failed opportunities to signal the danger posed by a stopped train in Wanaque on July 11, 1904, led to one of North Jersey’s deadliest train crashes.

The crash occurred shortly after a 12-car, chartered train stopped for water at a tower just north of the Midvale Station, near the Wanaque Reservoir. As the train sat, a flagman was supposed to stand behind the train to warn the approaching regular train of the obstruction.

Erie Railroad officials said the flagman did not go back far enough, and when the second train came around a curve, there was no stopping it. The chartered train on its way to Greenwood Lake was hit from behind by the second northbound train.

“As the trains crashed, part of the floor of the rear car of the special gave way, and as it telescoped into the rear car in front of it, heads were mowed down as if by a scythe,” The Record reported that day.

More than 40 people were severely injured. Seventeen died.

All were members of Hoboken’s First Plattdeutscher Club, a north German heritage club, which chartered a train for 800.

“Most of the dead also lived within five blocks of one another in Hoboken,” The Record reported.

The flagman, the operator, who Erie officials said also failed to put up a danger signal, the conductor and other staff from both trains were suspended and later fired.

The Record reported that a railroad expert said the accident may have come down to an overwhelmed steward of the Midvale Station, however.

“That unfortunate fellow had the responsibility of at least half a dozen branches of railroading on his shoulders. Is it any wonder he made a fatal mistake?” the expert was quoted as asking.

Email: zimmer@northjersey.com

search_result.title: What we know about the Adventureland accident that killed an 11 ...
search_result.text:
Michael Jaramillo, 11, died Sunday after he and three others were injured on the Raging River water ride at Adventureland Park in Altoona. One child remains in critical condition, and two others suffered minor injuries.

What happened on Raging River ride?

The Jaramillo family, of Marion, went to Adventureland to celebrate David Jaramillo's upcoming 16th birthday.

David, his younger brothers Gus, 14, and Michael, 11; their parents, Sabrina and David Jaramillo; and their 18-year-old cousin Nyla Pettie boarded a boat for the ride around 7:30 p.m. Saturday.

The family’s boat flipped over within 20 seconds of the ride beginning, according to pastor Christian Shields, of Christian Life Church in Cedar Rapids, causing all six to hit their heads on the surface below and trapping them in their seatbelts underneath the water.

Emergency responders and witnesses helped to free the riders. Four were taken to the hospital, and park officials said Sunday that they were "saddened" to learn that one had died.

The ride is closed and park officials said they are working with state and local authorities to investigate the cause of the accident.

More:Parents recount Raging River accident that killed 11-year-old son

16-year-old on life support

David Jaramillo, Michael's brother who turned 16 on Wednesday, has been in a medically induced coma at Blank Children’s Hospital since the accident, Shields said.

David has some brain function and has woken up a couple times at the Des Moines hospital, opening his eyes and asking what happened, he said. He remains hooked up to breathing machines, but doctors are hoping to wean him off life support, Shields said.

Support for the Jaramillo family

Christian Life Church in Cedar Rapids is sponsoring a GoFundMe page that has raised more than $40,000 for the family as of Thursday morning. The church is also held a prayer vigil from 7-8 p.m. Wednesday.

The few dozen at Christian Life Church in Cedar Rapids on Wednesday evening extended their hands out to the southwest corner of the room, toward Des Moines, and prayed for a full recovery for David Jaramillo.

"As a community and as a church, I know we've all been rocked by this tragedy," the Rev. Christian Shields, a pastor at the church, said at Wednesday's service dedicated to the family.

But nothing compares to what the Jaramillo family is going through — "all of the hurt, all of the pain, all of the anger," Shields said.

And David, "he's going to wake up to this and realize — 'I don't have my brother anymore,' " Shields said.

What is the family saying?

In an interview broadcast Tuesday on ABC's “Good Morning America,” David Jaramillo, Michael Jaramillo's father, recounted what happened when the boat capsized.

“When it flipped over, all of us were trapped in the safety seat belts," he said. "I see the silhouettes of my sons trying to grab each other, grab us. They want us to help them. We couldn't do it.”

David Jaramillo, 43, referred questions to his attorney, Ryan Best of Spokane, Washington, when reached by phone Tuesday.

"I feel like Adventureland robbed me of my baby,” said Sabrina Jaramillo, Michael’s mother, said on “Good Morning America." "I will never get a chance to see him grow up."

What are officials saying?

Altoona police spokeswoman Alyssa Wilson told the Associated Press on Sunday that detectives were working with park staff and state inspectors "to understand this tragic accident."

After being closed because of the pandemic last year, the ride last underwent an inspection on Friday. Attorney Guy Cook, who represents Adventureland in personal injury cases and is assisting with the park’s response, told the AP the ride was found to be in working order and passed its inspection before reopening to the public.

What do we know about the ride?

The Raging River ride first opened in 1983 and was manufactured by a Swiss company, Intamin Amusement Rides. It has been a staple of the park since its opening in June 1983 when then-Gov. Terry Branstad was even on one of the inaugural rides.

Adventureland advertises the ride as a "great way to cool off with the whole family," warning it might leave participants soaked. Riders are sent through rapids on large circular rafts using a conveyor belt.

The ride closed in 2020 due to the pandemic and reopened on July 3, the day of the accident.

Although under different circumstances, this is the second accident connected to the ride. In 2016, Steve Booher died while helping riders get off the ride's raft.

It was Intamin’s Maryland office that handled the Raging River design and build project. Heading the team of 15 people involved in designing the ride was Peter Schnabel, a native of Munich, Germany.

"The idea for the Raging River ride came from the 1976 Olympic Games in Munich," Schnabel told the Des Moines Register in 1983. Intamin, which got its start designing and building ski tows and cable cars, was involved in designing the man-made kayak course for those games.

A mandatory “major breakdown" report Adventureland filed with the state after the accident and released under a public records request said at least one of the raft's eight air bladders was deflated.

Adventureland attorney Guy Cook told the Associated Press the bladder could have deflated upon overturning, arguing it's premature to draw any conclusions. He said it was the first time one of the rafts had flipped out of tens of thousands of launches in the ride's 38-year history.

The failure came just one day after an annual state inspection of the ride. The inspector rated the ride as satisfactory in 19 categories — including emergency procedures, seat belts and safety restraints, records show.

The ride had passed inspections for at least the past five years, according to the records.

Iowa Labor Commissioner Rod Roberts, whose agency conducted the inspections, declined to be interviewed Wednesday and did not immediately respond to written questions.

Inspectors have reviewed at least 15 other accidents at Adventureland in the past decade and 38 since 2006, records show.

Those accidents include the 2016 death of an employee who fell into the water when he was helping people off the Raging River ride. Records show the Iowa Occupational Safety and Health Administration fined Adventureland $4,500 in connection with his death.

Inspectors described three other accidents on the ride as minor. Several on other Adventureland rides have led to severe trauma.

Those included a rider whose foot was trapped between the platform and a train, two workers who suffered severed fingers and a child who was hospitalized after being hit by a loose board while riding a roller coaster.

Who was Steve Booher?

Booher, 68, died while working on the ride after only six days on his summer job at Adventureland. He was helping riders get out of the ride's rafts when he fell on the conveyor belt, fracturing his skull and suffering a major brain injury. He died four days later. Last December, the park settled a wrongful death lawsuit brought by Booher's wife of 47 years and their adult children for an undisclosed sum.

Iowa Occupational Safety and Health Administration fined the park $4,500 after Booher's death, the maximum the agency could assess for that type of violation.

Cook said there was no commonality between the two accidents, but that he could not comment on Saturday's accident until the investigation is complete.

More on Booher's death:

Other Adventureland accidents

Court records show Adventureland has been sued in recent years by people who were seriously injured on other rides, including waterslides.

Iowa OSHA records show the agency most recently fined Adventureland in 2018, after an employee working on a roller coaster was knocked off a transformer and fell to the ground when he was struck by a test ride. The employee was hospitalized with a broken arm. Adventureland settled safety violations by agreeing to pay $14,500 in 2019.

More:Adventureland fined $37,000 after Dragon roller coaster car hits worker

History of the park

Jack Krantz was a well-known home builder in the Des Moines area when he set his sights on opening an amusement park.

"He owned a company called Custom Built Homes for a number of years, then he decided he was going to build something bigger," Molly Vincent, Jack's daughter and the park's marketing director, said.

More: Adventureland Amusement Park forever changed entertainment in central Iowa

Other sites were considered, but Krantz eventually settled on Altoona, a town of about 3,000 at the time.

That first season, Adventureland was a far cry from the acres of towering roller coasters and water rides found there today.

"It was a Sky Ride in the middle of a cornfield is what it seemed like," John Krantz said.

But the people came. Attendance topped 300,000.

The park's Main Town area — an idea borrowed from Disney World — was free to guests who could cross a bridge for admission to the park itself, which included an assortment of smaller rides like the Jaunty Jeeps, Silly Silo, River Rapids and Bavarian Scrambler.

From 2015: Last ride for Adventureland's Log Ride

The next year brought the Lady Luck and the Flitzer, a small mountain-scene roller coaster. Three years later another Tornado arrived with the opening of the park's iconic wooden roller coaster.

"It started with Petunia Pig, the fiberglass sculpture in the middle of the park, and it just got kind of out of hand from there," Vincent said.

Since then the 183-acre park has continued to add rides at a rate of about one every two years.

"Sometimes we get a little excited and put two in, or sometimes we build an entire water park in two years," Vincent said.

Completed in 2012, the water park — with its assortment of pools, water and tube slides, and lazy river — was the single largest addition in the park's history.

"It blew up beyond any of our expectations," Vincent said.

Other recent additions include:

The Storm Chaser (2014), which spins riders around the top of a 260-foot tower, offering those brave enough a scenic glimpse of downtown Des Moines.

The Monster (2016), which is 2,500 feet long and reaches a top speed of 65 mph. It includes a 133-foot vertical lift hill followed by a 101-degree drop — steeper than any ride in Iowa. It replaced the Log Ride, which gave its last rides in 215.

The Phoenix (2018), a four-seat car that spins 360 degrees as it goes up and down hills. The $6 million roller coaster replaced the Inverter, a ride that was discontinued in 2017 off the main boulevard. The Super Screamer was there until 1999. Maurer Rides, a company from Germany, is built the roller coaster, which reaches speeds of 40 mph and over 50 feet in height, Vincent said.

The Dragon Slayer (2021), a 4D free spin coaster from Utah-based S&S Sansei Technologies. Molly Vincent, a spokesperson for Adventureland, told the Register in March that each car has sets of outboard seats that can spin forward and backward independently as the coaster weaves along its course.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

search_result.title: 'Action Point' revives past of Mountain Creek Waterpark as Action Park
search_result.text:
VERNON — As it prepares to open its 2018 season Saturday, a new Hollywood movie is forcing Mountain Creek Waterpark to confront the troubled legacy of its predecessor, Action Park.

Johnny Knoxville's "Action Point," released June 1, is loosely based on real stories of broken bones, concussions and deaths that made Action Park, which formerly occupied the Mountain Creek site, among the most notorious theme parks in the nation.

The movie uses a ramshackle amusement park as a catapult to launch self-injuring stuntman Johnny Knoxville of “Jackass” fame into various pratfalls. The name “Action Point” is an homage to its North Jersey inspiration, Knoxville has told several media outlets.

As the park's 1980s advertising tag line boasted: “There’s nothing in the world like Action Park.”

There was the short-lived and dangerous Cannonball Loop, an enclosed water slide featuring a complete vertical loop that required participants to be freshly hosed down lest they became stuck.

There was the Tidal Wave Pool, nicknamed the Grave Pool, which could generate waves more than 3 feet high and was the site of three drownings.

There was also the Alpine Slide, a luge-track of fiberglass and concrete set on a ski hill that would fling occasionally brake-less carts into slower ones and leave lasting skid marks on riders unable to abide by the “keep your arms and legs in at all times” rule.

The ride registered the park’s first death in July 1980, when an employee's cart jumped the track. The 19-year-old struck his head on a rock.

“It was the Wild West before 1996,” said Joe Hession, Mountain Creek president. “As much as the stories are interesting, I almost see them as stories of 'let’s make sure that never happens again.' ”

Action Park deaths, injuries piled up

Hundreds of injuries and six deaths were recorded in the 18 years after the grand opening of Action Park in 1978.

Deaths and injuries • A 19-year-old Action Park worker died after his cart jumped the track and he hit his head on a rock. • A 20-year-old Brooklyn man drowned on Aug. 25, 1987, in the Tidal Wave Pool. An 18-year-old from Queens drowned in the same pool on July 19, 1987. • Hundreds of injuries and six deaths were recorded in the 18 years after the grand opening in 1978.

The regular injuries and attitude surrounding them led to the creation of park nicknames: Traction Park, Class Action Park, Accident Park.

Underage drinking, missing signage and lax safety cemented the park’s reputation as a utopia for rambunctious teens.

“It’s fun to tell the stories,” Hession said. “But, yeah, we’re glorifying criminals. We’re glorifying people who conducted a business that really, as much as it might be funny, hurt people. I mean, people died there.”

As a Vernon native and a former general manager of the resort, Hession said he is familiar with the park’s various iterations. Before he joined the Intrawest Resorts Holdings management team, his first job was parking cars at the resort.

During the Action Park days, the ethos was to choose your own adventure and danger level, Hession said. Rides were tested until perfected.

The story continues below the video.

Action Park became Mountain Creek

Intrawest Resorts Holdings, a developer and operator of destination resorts, arrived in 1996 after a string of lawsuits against Action Park. The company changed the park's name to Mountain Creek and embarked on a mission to revive the park by installing new, safer rides and removing old ones.

Hession said he quickly accepted that rides with recurring incidents had to close. Fans of the old Action Park, however, were resentful, he said.

The story continues below gallery.

“It was really quite a process to make it a safe park,” he said. “We removed a lot of things, and in the '90s I remember people saying, ‘You’re getting rid of this, but it’s the best thing.’ It was a commitment to safety. It was a commitment to being good stewards of recreation overall.”

After a six-year absence, Hession returned to Mountain Creek’s staff roughly six months ago with his management team from SNOW Operating, which works with ski resorts such as Aspen Snowmass and Whistler Blackcomb on a consulting basis with its Terrain Based Learning Program.

The resort’s ownership group recently shed the Mulvihill family, which opened Action Park in 1978 and returned after the Intrawest era in 2010.

The family revived the name Action Park and its trademark technicolor signage in 2014 to capitalize on nostalgic feelings from now-adult teenagers. “I survived Action Park” T-shirts and bumper stickers further glamorized the danger for two years until the name Mountain Creek returned.

“It could be the subject of a business school course about what not to do,” Hession said.

The park’s dangerous reputation made a brief return in 2012, when it racked up more injuries in one year than it did from 2005 through 2009.

Try this:Want to torture yourself? Try Mountain Creek's aerial ropes course

Recreation:16 places for cooling down this summer

Theme Parks:Jungle Habitat in West Milford needs a new name — any ideas?

Cannonball Falls, Colorado River: Injuries continue

An enclosed ride that launched riders from a twisting tube into a pool 10-feet below called Cannonball Falls was the most dangerous ride in the state in 2012, with 12 injuries, state records show. The Colorado River ride was a close second, with 11 injuries in 2012.

Cannonball Falls has since been closed. The Colorado River ride now requires helmets after multiple reports of passengers bumping heads. The Tarzan Swing was shut down last year to examine safer operation, Hession said. The Alpine Slide was replaced with the Alpine Coaster.

“You can’t do what used to be done,” said Chris Haggerty, the director of resort operations, who started working at the resort as a teenage lifeguard. “You wouldn’t want to, either. You’d go out of business.”

Today, the park’s focus is on safely providing thrills, rather than using danger to boost adrenaline for its 250,000 customers each year, Hession said. In the past four years, the park has tallied between 26 and 33 injuries each summer, state records show.

The last severe injury, on Thunder Falls in August 2015, was credited to inadvertent rider misbehavior, records show.

In addition to a renewed focus on safety, the water park in 2018 and beyond will attempt to become more well-rounded for full family outings, Hession said. Many popular rides, including the 99-foot-tall H2-Oh-No! and the horizontal-looping Zero-G, are high thrill, he said.

The future of Mountain Creek

This year, the park is set to introduce its first 4D water slide, Hession said. A relatively new phenomenon, the ride includes a light and sound experience. This specific one features a snow theme to reflect the park’s winter sport connection, he said.

Other technological advancements have been installed to facilitate entry into the park using online purchasing options, Hession said.

The park is open only on weekends through June 17. Then, the summer weekday schedule runs until closing day on Sept. 3. Daily tickets cost about $30. A season pass is now available for $64.99.

search_result.title: Stevie Nicks and the 22 men who are double Rock Hall of Fame ...
search_result.text:
On March 29, Stevie Nicks will be inducted to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame a second time.

The Phoenix native first was inducted for her work with Fleetwood Mac in 1988. Now, she's about to be inducted for her solo work as well, making her the first and only female artist inducted twice.

In an interview with Rolling Stone, Nicks said, "My biggest hope is that I have opened the door due to the fact that there’s 22 men who have gone in twice and zero women. I think that’s really a little off balance. That’s what I’m hoping."

In the meantime, here's a look at the other artists with two or more inductions since the first class was enshrined in 1986.

Clyde McPhatter

The Hall of Fame was in its third year of inducted artists when this legendary soul sensation got his second nod. He was inducted as a solo artist first, in 1987, and then re-inducted one year later as a member of the Drifters. The Rock Hall website credits McPhatter with having "possessed a unique vocal instrument, a lively high tenor that captured the promise and fervor of the teenage Fifties" and being among the first singers "to cross over from the church to the pop and R&B charts."

Eric Clapton

The man has been inducted three times, first as a member of the Yardbirds (1992), then one year later for his work with Cream and finally, in recognition of his solo work in the year 2000. As it says on the Rock Hall website: "THREE INDUCTIONS, THREE WORDS: 'CLAPTON IS GOD.'" That expression – the ultimate fan note – was famously spray-painted on a wall in 1967 and has followed the guitarist around through the succeeding decades. Clapton is said to have found the phrased embarrassing.

John Lennon

John Lennon was inducted as a member of the Beatles in 1988. He was inducted as a solo artist six years later by his former writing partner, Paul McCartney, who recalled some of his favorite memories of their life together in a touching speech. The Hall website praises "a solo career marked by experimentation, political activism, embrace of the counterculture and more enduring songs: 'Imagine,' 'Working Class Hero,' 'Instant Karma!' and '#9 Dream,'" saying he proved that musicians could reinvent themselves.

Jimmy Page

Of course he's in there as a member of Led Zeppelin. As the Rock Hall sums it up, "Hard rock and heavy metal as we know it wouldn't exist without Led Zeppelin, one of the most popular and innovate rock bands ever." By the time they took their rightful place in 1995, though, the guitarist had already been been inducted three years earlier with psychedelic pioneers the Yardbirds. Led Zeppelin's first tour, as it happens, was billed as the New Yardbirds, having been initially assembled to honor a touring commitment.

David Crosby

He was inducted with the Byrds in 1991 and then again in 1997 for his work with Crosby, Stills & Nash. The Byrds, of course, were folk-rock pioneers, for which they would have been inducted either way. But as the Hall notes, they were also "the ever-evolving pioneers of rock and roll's expansion into new, psychedelic sounds." As for CSN, the Hall praises the trio's "impeccable harmonies" and their "thoughtful, song-centric approach to music, penning folk hits with messages of change, hope and forward motion."

Stephen Stills

I'll tell you, 1997 was a banner year for Stephen Stills, the only Hall of Famer to have been inducted twice in the same ceremony – as a member of Buffalo Springfield and the final word in Crosby, Stills & Nash. As the Rock Hall website puts it, "During their short tenure as a band, Buffalo Springfield brought together brilliant songwriters and musical powerhouses that set the tone for Seventies folk- and country-rock." Stills wrote and sang their most iconic song, "For What it's Worth."

Neil Young

Although his tenure in Buffalo Springfield actually predates his solo career, Young was inducted as a solo artist first, in 1995. And that seems about right. As the first line of his Rock Hall bio puts it, he is "one of rock and roll’s greatest songwriters and performers." He's also praised as "a musical nomad who follows his muse wherever it leads, from folk to rock and roll to rockabilly to blues and back again." Has that restlessness at times confounded fans? Of course it has. But there are those who swear by "Trans." And truthfully, he should be in as part of Crosby, Stills & Nash as well. He makes them better.

Paul McCartney

"Did you know Paul McCartney was in a band before Wings?" was an inexplicably popular joke in the '70s. His first induction was in 1988 for that band before Wings, the act you've known for all these years. Wings never made it to the Rock Hall. But they surely factored into his induction as a solo act in 1999. As the Hall website sums up the case for his solo induction, his "commitment to progress has not only kept McCartney relevant— it's ensured he's had one of the most intriguing, varied music careers ever."

Curtis Mayfield

He was inducted for his work with the Impressions first, in 1991, and re-inducted for his solo work in 1999. The Rock Hall writes that his solo career, which began in 1970, is "significant for the forthright way in which he addressed issues of black identity and self-awareness," going on to cite his influence on artists such as Lenny Kravitz, Ice-T, Public Enemy and Arrested Development. "Mayfield’s ability to voice hard truths through funky, uplifting music," the Hall notes, "has rendered him one of the great soul icons."

Paul Simon

Inducted with Simon & Garfunkel in 1990, he was re-inducted for his solo career in 2001. The Rock Hall website praised him as a "master wordsmith... whose lyrics are as keen as his melodies are tuneful," going on to enthuse that he "seems to absorb influences from every corner of the world and then give them back in the form of beautiful, textured songs. While his eclectic tastes are ever-evolving, he can always be counted on for affecting, poetic lyrics."

Michael Jackson

Jackson was inducted with the other members of the Jackson 5 in 1997 on the strength of Motown classics like "I Want You Back." He was inducted as a solo artist in 2001. ("Thriller" is still the biggest-selling album in the world.) The Rock Hall says, "The future King of Pop carried soul and R&B into the mainstream in the '70s with the Jackson 5, and then leveraged music videos and smart collaborations to become a beloved global superstar in the '80s." Reports indicate that Jackson's two inductions will not be revoked following the release of "Leaving Neverland," an HBO documentary in which two men allege that Jackson sexually abused them as children.

George Harrison

In 2004, he became the third Beatle to be twice-inducted, enshrined for a solo career that was launched with the masterful "All Things Must Pass," a triple album that opened the floodgates for an artist often overshadowed by his more prolific bandmates. As the Rock Hall summed it up, "The 'Quiet Beatle' took his inner conflict between fame and privacy, secular and sacred, and turned it into a huge body of work" that "introduced the Western world to Eastern musical and spiritual influences."

John E. Carter

He may not be a household name, but Carter was inducted with two legendary vocal groups – the Flamingos (2001) and the Dells (2004). The Flamingos' biggest hit was "I Only Have Eyes for You." The Rock Hall says, "Today they stand as one of the most sophisticated doo wop groups and most influential vocal groups." At the time of their induction, the Dells, who topped the R&B charts with "Stay in My Corner" and "Oh, What a Night," were one of very few groups to have a hit in every decade since the '50s.

Jeff Beck

The guitarist was inducted with the Yardbirds first in 1992 and again for his solo career in 2009. As the Rock Hall raved, "Double-inductee Jeff Beck is a visionary, an innovator and a true virtuoso. He built his first guitar at age 15 and learned the instrument inside and out before mastering everything from heavy metal to jazz." The website also noted that his "urgent, in-your-face guitar was so expressive that he din't need a singer." That is true, but we're still glad he did those records with the Yardbirds and Rod Stewart.

Sammy Strain

Strain was inducted with the O'Jays in 2005 and with Little Anthony & the Imperials in 2009. The Rock Hall calls the O'Jays "the pinnacle of '70s soul music... instrumental in popularizing Philly soul and the work of songwriting team Gamble and Huff. Their velvety, lush, yet funk-tinged sound establishes them as some of soul music’s finest." Strain came to that group from the Imperials, "one of the finest vocal groups to emerge from the talent-rich New York scene" in the Rock Hall's estimation.

Graham Nash

It's kind of crazy that the Hollies went in after Crosby, Stills & Nash. But they finally made it in in 2010. That's a long time to wait for a band the Rock Hall website credits with being "one of the most commercially successful bands of the British Invasion" whose "rich, multi-part harmonies — sung over consistently sharp beat-group arrangements — made them one of the most musically appealing and popular bands" of that Invasion. But then, the Hall has always been a bit weighted in favor of American success.

Ronnie Wood

The guitarist was inducted with the Rolling Stones in 1989 and his previous group, the Small Faces/Faces, in 2012. He's been a Rolling Stone since replacing Mick Taylor in 1975. And that makes him the longest-running Stones guitarist not named Keith. But for all his contributions to the Stones' career since signing on, they would've been inducted if he'd never joined at all, whereas his contributions the Faces' legacy is undeniable, including a co-writing credit on "Stay With Me," their most successful U.S. hit.

Rod Stewart

Stewart was inducted for his solo work in 1994 and The Small Faces/Faces in 2012. He's one of rock and roll's most soulful vocalists, from those early recordings with Python Lee Jackson through the Faces and the Jeff Beck Group to "Maggie May" and "Every Picture Tells a Story." As the Rock Hall puts it, "There is no mistaking the warm, grizzly rasp of Rod Stewart's voice," pronouncing the star "irresistibly charming and undeniably talented" blessed with "one of the finest voices of his generation."

Peter Gabriel

Inducted with Genesis in 2010, he was honored again in 2014 for a solo career whose highlights range from "Games Without Frontiers" to the five-times-platinum, mainstream-courting triumph, "So." He steered Genesis through their most eccentric work on progressive-rock landmarks as iconic as "The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway." Of his solo years, the Rock all writes, "Peter Gabriel has taken on as many different roles post-Genesis as the theatrical roles he assumed as the band’s frontman."

Lou Reed

In making the case for the Velvet Underground's long-overdue induction (1995), the Hall cited conventional music-nerd wisdom: "Not everyone bought their album, but everyone who did started a band." Reed was their streetwise visionary, penning Velvet gems as timeless as "I'm Waiting for the Man" and "Heroin." Add in his solo years for what the Hall calls "a body of work that ranks with Dylan and Lennon-McCartney as among the most significant and influential songwriting catalogues of the 20th century."

Ringo Starr

This one needs an asterisk. He's in there twice, both as a Beatle (1988) and on his own. But his induction in 2015 was an Award for Musical Excellence, which "honors those musicians, producers and others who have spent their careers out of the spotlight working with major artists on various parts of their recording and live careers." In other words, that honor lets us factor in his drumming with the Beatles, which was never less than stellar. As the Hall sums what makes him shine: "He is a song-serving drummer."

Gregg Rolie

The final pre-Nicks member of the twice-inducted club joined as a member of Santana (1998) and Journey (2017). Rolie sang on several of Santana's greatest early hits, including "Black Magic Woman" "Oye Como Va" and "Evil Ways," taking part in their show-stopping set at the Woodstock Music and Art Festival in 1969. In 1973, he joined fellow Santana expatriate Neal Schon in Journey, playing keyboards on their first six albums and singing lead of many of those pre-Steve Perry records.

search_result.title: Detroit's The Spinners headed to Rock & Roll Hall of Fame
search_result.text:
The Spinners will be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in November, as part of the 2023 class announced Wednesday morning.

The long-running R&B group will become the 21st Detroit artist enshrined in the rock hall since its 1986 launch.

Not making Wednesday’s cut were rock duo The White Stripes, who were part of a 14-artist nominees shortlist revealed in February. Their omission is somewhat surprising: Artists named to the ballot in their first year of eligibility, as The White Stripes were, typically win induction that same year.

The Spinners are part of an inductees list that includes Willie Nelson, George Michael, Missy Elliott, Sheryl Crow, Rage Against the Machine and Kate Bush.

They were selected by a body of 1,000-plus artists, historians and other music professionals, combined with a public vote. The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony will be held Nov. 3 at the Barclays Center in New York.

"I am in shock and tears and feeling so grateful," said Claudreen Jackson, widow of late Spinners bass singer Pervis Jackson. "Pervis would have been humbled and amazed. The thing about the Spinners was that however high their career went, they were still humble and thankful. They were first class onstage and offstage. I’m just so happy this has happened for them."

The Spinners, who formed in Ferndale in the 1950s and did a stint with Motown before bigger success with Atlantic Records in the ‘70s, were triumphant Wednesday after three previous RRHOF nominations. With rich harmonies and an ear for catchy material, the group piled up pop and R&B hits such as “Could It Be I’m Falling in Love,” “One of a Kind (Love Affair),” “Then Came You,” “Games People Play," “The Rubberband Man” and "Working My Way Back to You."

Working with producer Thom Bell, the Spinners became closely associated with the Philly sound that prevailed in ‘70s R&B. The group remains active, although the last remaining original member, 84-year-old baritone Henry Fambrough, recently announced his retirement.

The current incarnation of the group is scheduled to perform May 20 with the Stylistics at Music Hall in Detroit.

search_result.title: He gives the world hope: Willie Nelson inducted into the Rock & Roll ...
search_result.text:
Willie Nelson, revered country artist and patron saint of Austin, joined the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame on Friday.

After accepting his trophy from Dave Matthews, Willie reflected on the "long ride" from his first job as a DJ to becoming a country music legend in the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame. Willie recalled playing early songs by Elvis Presley.

"Now I remember writers calling that rockabilly rather than rock 'n' roll. And I never did pay much attention to categories, and I'm not sure the fans did either," he said.

More:Top 10 moments from Willie's 90th: George Strait, Keith Richards, the Chicks and more

In his career he logged collaborations with Jerry Lee Lewis and his "buddy" Ray Charles. "And when Ray and I got together, we never asked each other what to do or whether to do a soul song or a rock song or a country song. We just sang the songs we love," he said.

It was one of many occasions when Willie rejected rigid genre delineation.

"Everyone thought we were crazy — and we were — to do 'Stardust,' our album of standards, but it turned out pretty good," he said. Released in 1978, "Stardust" was certified quadruple platinum in 1990.

Noting that he and Johnny Cash, half of his band of outlaws, the Highwaymen, are now in the hall, he made a case for "Waylon (Jennings), who played with Buddy Holly, and Kris (Kristofferson), who sang so many hits," to be inducted, too. (Bernie Taupin also mentioned Jennings during his acceptance speech.)

For subscribers:Willie's country: 'The patron saint of Austin' reshaped a genre and the Texas capital

Surrounded by his family band and Chris Stapleton, Willie performed "Whiskey River." He let Stapleton do the heavy lifting on the vocals, singing the choruses and picking on his guitar Trigger like a champ. Then Sheryl Crow put in her best Patsy Cline on a duet with Willie on "Crazy."

During her own speech earlier in the evening Crow, who celebrated Willie Nelson's 90th birthday at the Hollywood Bowl earlier this year, said it was an honor to be inducted into the hall with "one of the people I admire most on this planet, Willie Nelson."

'His heart is genuine':11 quotes about Willie Nelson that capture his legacy

Crow, Stapleton and Matthews all joined Willie and Family for a rollicking rendition of "On the Road Again" that drew a standing ovation that lasted for minutes.

Before Willie took the stage, Matthews sang an acoustic "Funny How Time Slips Away." Then a video tribute, which opened with a clip of Johnny Cash duetting with Willie on "Crazy," traced the Red-Headed Stranger's transition from his buttoned up Nashville years to his musical rebirth as an outlaw in Austin. It included everyone from Ray Charles to Chris Stapleton and Norah Jones singing his praises. It also chronicled Willie's advocacy for family farms and cannabis.

A visibly nervous Matthews, who stumbled through a brief history of career highlights and anecdotes as an introduction to the video, summed up his remarks with a list of troubles that make our modern world feel "upside down."

"It's enough for you to give up on the world," he said. "But it's people like Willie Nelson that made me hopeful for us all. Through his words and through his music. And through the example he sets."

The other artists inducted into the Hall of Fame this year were Kate Bush, Sheryl Crow, Missy Elliott, George Michael, Rage Against the Machine, the Spinners, DJ Kool Herc, Link Wray, Chaka Khan, Al Kooper, Bernie Taupin and Don Cornelius.

search_result.title: Eminem headed to Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, leading 2022 ...
search_result.text:
Eminem will be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame this fall, swept into the hall in his first year of eligibility and becoming the 20th Detroit performer enshrined in the institution’s 36-year history.

The Detroit rapper is the second hip-hop solo artist to make the Hall of Fame while alive, following Jay-Z last year.

The rock hall’s 2022 class was revealed Wednesday morning. Eminem will be joined by Pat Benatar, Duran Duran, Eurythmics, Dolly Parton, Carly Simon and longtime Motown Records artist Lionel Richie.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame ceremony will be held Nov. 5 at L.A.'s Microsoft Theater. The show will air subsequently on HBO and HBO Max streaming.

Striking out for a sixth time was the MC5, the Detroit band whose high-octane counterculture music helped set the stage for hard rock and punk.

Eminem’s Hall of Fame feat joins a long list of accolades for the 49-year-old star, including 15 Grammys, 17 Billboard Music Awards, a pair of diamond-selling albums, an Oscar and numerous “best rapper” citations.

The seven inductees unveiled Wednesday were drawn from a list of 17 nominees announced in February. The finalists were selected by 1,000-plus artists, historians and other music professionals, combined with voting by the public.

More:Restoring Hitsville, U.S.A: A peek at a little-known part of the Motown Museum expansion

More:$25 ticket sale includes Chris Rock, Ted Nugent, Miranda Lambert metro Detroit shows

By making the Hall of Fame in his first year of eligibility, Eminem joins a select list of first-year, first-ballot inductees. Since 2000, there have been 21 such Hall of Famers. Eminem is the only 2022 artist with that status.

Artists qualify for induction 25 years after their first commercial release. Eminem’s debut album, “Infinite,” landed in November 1996, when he was a little-known figure on the Detroit hip-hop scene. That indie release — recorded at an obscure 8 Mile Road studio and issued on 500 copies, half cassettes and half LPs — came three years before Eminem broke globally with “The Slim Shady LP” on Interscope Records.

Related: Eminem's 'Slim Shady LP': An oral history of the album that created a superstar

“Infinite” was an early taste of Eminem’s tongue-twisting, internal-rhyming rap skills and confrontational but soul-baring approach. It was followed by hit albums such as “The Slim Shady LP,” “The Marshall Mathers LP” and “The Eminem Show,” which helped him become the best-selling U.S. recording artist in the first decade of the 2000s.

Eminem is the seventh hip-hop act inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, following the late Notorious B.I.G. and groups such as Run-DMC and N.W.A.

The Hall of Fame has incorporated fan voting in recent years, though like many of the institution’s tightly guarded procedures, its weight in the final tally is murky. Duran Duran led this year’s fan ballot with about 935,000 votes, followed by Eminem (684,000), Pat Benatar (631,000), Eurythmics (442,000) and Dolly Parton (334,000).

Will Eminem show up for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame festivities this autumn? That remains to be seen. The show typically features a tribute speech and performance segment for each inductee, followed by a show-ending group jam.

It’s worth noting Eminem is an artist who isn’t exactly keen on public appearances. He even skipped his own Oscars triumph in 2003, when “Lose Yourself” (from “8 Mile”) took the Academy Award for best original song.

Still, Eminem has a history with the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. In 2009, he presented the induction of Run-DMC, and last year he performed with LL Cool J as the veteran rapper was honored with the Award for Musical Excellence.

search_result.title: Eminem inducted into Rock & Roll Hall of Fame
search_result.text:
LOS ANGELES — Eminem’s musical journey started in hungry desperation at an obscure studio on 8 Mile Road. Saturday night, it led him into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.

The Detroit rapper, in one the most triumphant moments of his much-decorated career, was enshrined in the rock hall during a long, star-filled ceremony at the Microsoft Theater. Eminem, inducted by Dr. Dre and joined by Ed Sheeran and Steven Tyler during his musical performance, became the 20th Detroit inductee in the institution’s 36-year history.

“I realize what an honor it is right now for me to be up here tonight, and what a privilege it is to do the music that I love — the music that basically saved my life,” Eminem said, clad in a black leather hoodie and donning a pair of glasses to read his handwritten acceptance speech.

Eminem has long been uneasy with the celebrity spotlight, and he reaffirmed it Saturday, declining to walk the red carpet and rarely looking up as he delivered his speech. “This part I’m not crazy about,” he said, gesturing down at his notes.

Rather than devoting his big moment to indulge in his career accomplishments, he spent nearly half his time at the podium saluting the “groundbreaking artists” in hip-hop who inspired his work. For 3½ minutes, he read an alphabetical list of more than 100 names, famous and obscure — fittingly slipping into a rhythmic flow as he rattled them off.

“I would not be me without them,” he concluded. “I’m a high-school dropout with a hip-hop education, and these are my teachers. It’s their night just as much as it is mine.”

Eminem’s segment came late in a nearly six-hour show that included the inductions of Duran Duran, Pat Benatar, Carly Simon, Lionel Richie, the Eurythmics and Dolly Parton.

It was a news-making affair that included Duran Duran’s shock revelation that guitarist Andy Taylor, absent Saturday night, is suffering from terminal prostate cancer.

Parton, dependably humble and still seeming a bit mystified by her inclusion in the rock hall, debuted a new song with a vintage rock ‘n’ roll feel.

John Mellencamp, inducting his attorney Allen Grubman for a non-performer honor, seemed to have Kanye West’s recent dustup in mind when he called out antisemitism during a hard-edged speech, saying, “(screw) anybody who says anything in that manner.”

The hall of fame ceremony will air at 8 p.m. Nov. 19 on HBO, when it will also become available for streaming on HBO Max.

Eminem, the rock hall’s seventh hip-hop honoree, was inducted by his longtime collaborator Dr. Dre in front of an audience that included daughter Hailie, manager Paul Rosenberg, producers Jeff and Mark Bass and other Michiganders crucial to his career.

Dre’s eight-minute introduction lauded Eminem as an against-the-odds white rapper who went on to become the best-selling artist in hip-hop history and one of the top-selling acts in the annals of popular music.

Dre recounted his first encounter with Eminem's music in the late ‘90s.

“I guess it was my ignorance at the time, thinking that, ‘OK, if you’re a good rapper, you must be black,’” Dre said, going on to add: “While everyone else around me had their doubts, I knew his gifts were undeniable.”

Dre noted that Eminem has never concerned himself with sales figures and other industry benchmarks.

“What’s most important to him is that he’s earned the respect of his peers as one of the best to ever do it,” Dre said. “Turns out, this unassuming white guy with blue eyes from Detroit (turned) everything we thought we knew about hip-hop on its head by forcing us to confront our own biases, pulling not only the genre but all of us right along with him.”

For his live performance Saturday, backed by the event’s house band, Eminem stalked the stage with friend and longtime hype man Denaun Porter near his side, while DJ Alchemist manned the decks behind them.

His medley of hits launched with the song that had ignited it all, 1999’s “My Name Is,” followed by the rapid-fire marvel of “Rap God” and its tongue-twisting broadside of syllables, which had the Microsoft Theater energized and at its feet, nearly five hours into the hall of fame show.

Aerosmith’s Steven Tyler was a surprise guest, hitting the stage with his trademark scarf-draped mic to lend his “Dream On” vocals to Eminem’s “Sing for the Moment.” Ed Sheeran had the next unannounced cameo, manning an acoustic guitar as he served up the Dido vocal parts for “Stan.”

“Forever” and “Not Afraid” rounded out a set that found Eminem looking vital and compelling in his musical element. He hasn’t played a full-scale concert in more than three years — in part because of the pandemic — but Saturday showed he can rise to the occasion as needed.

His Rock & Roll Hall of Fame honor, which will give him a permanent spot in the institution’s Cleveland museum, was a testament from the wider music establishment of his artistic and commercial clout.

Eminem joined an elite roll call of RRHOF artists inducted during their first year of eligibility, or 25 years after their first commercial release, and he was alone among Saturday’s inductees with that status.

In his case, the operative album was 1996’s “Infinite,” recorded at an 8 Mile Road home studio and pressed on 500 records and 500 cassettes he could hardly give away at the time. “Infinite” came three years before Eminem broke onto the global stage and went to become the best-selling music act in the first decade of the 2000s.

His ear for hip-hop authenticity was matched by an individual flair, including a percussive flow as noted by Jay-Z in a video tribute Saturday night. Armed with the alter ego Slim Shady, his music was at turns comedic, dark, vicious and vulnerable, culminating with the signature hit “Lose Yourself” — backdrop to his starring role in the film “8 Mile,” which hit theaters 20 years ago this week.

Eminem turned 50 last month, a life milestone that lends an air of gravitas against the brash-and-mouthy persona of his early years. Still, he was by far the youngest of Saturday’s seven inductees.

Born Marshall Mathers in Kansas City and raised in troubled family circumstances in and around Detroit, his music came from a distinct Motor City music tradition that was aggressive, colorful and designed to shock.

Backstage Saturday, fellow Detroit-bred star Alice Cooper commended the versatility of Eminem’s work.

“He was by far the funniest,” Cooper said. “I don’t think he ever got the right credit for the humor involved.”

The hall of fame’s glitzy festivities seemed far removed from Eminem’s rough-and-tumble life in the ‘90s, when he was a young father and aspiring rapper often scrambling for gas money and diapers. But he kept things real and straightforward during Saturday’s ceremony, seemingly conscious that where he came from is vital to who he is.
