search_result.title: Delaware lowers tax rate on casinos' slot and table games revenue
search_result.text:
The odds are finally paying off for Delaware's three casinos.

The state House late Thursday night passed a compromise bill that virtually assures the gaming houses will win the tax relief they have been seeking for nearly a decade.

"They can breath a little easier tonight knowing that the ball is back in their court," said longtime casino champion Sen. Brian Bushweller, D-Dover. "They've got a good future."

Approved 35-4, the latest draft of the bill would lower the casinos' tax burden $16.8 million by reducing the tax rate on slot revenue by 1 percentage point and cutting the tax rate on table games nearly in half.

Bushweller said that should provide significant breathing room for the casinos, which collectively employ close to 3,000 people — mostly in Kent County where Dover Downs Hotel and Casino and Harrington Casino and Raceway operate.

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

Those businesses have long argued Delaware's tax structure is threatening their ability to stay afloat in the face of growing competition from surrounding states.

Delaware has hiked the tax rate on casinos seven times since it legalized slot machines in the mid-1990s.

Most notably, the Legislature upped the rate on slot machine revenue to 43 percent in 2009 to help close a state budget gap during the height of the recession. That's nearly double the rate when the industry began.

The state also collects nearly 30 percent of all gross revenue generated by table games and another $3 million a year in table game licensing fees.

"If you look at what the industry has generated for the state over the years, it's close to $4 billion," said Denis McGlynn, the CEO of Dover Downs.

"We are in a partnership with the state, along with the horse racing industry, and I think this legislation shows lawmakers are grasping that we need all three partners to be healthy," he said. "Our financial situation last year shows that's not the case."

Dover Downs, the only publicly traded casino in Delaware, reported losses of more than $1 million in 2017 — a deficit that came after the casino paid $75 million to the state and the Delaware Standardbred Owners Association.

"We've overtaxed this industry," said Rep. William Carson, D-Smyrna. "We needed it at the time but we got it back to where it belongs."

Bushweller, who will retire at the end of 2018, has been working for years to secure a tax break for the casinos. He managed to convince lawmakers in 2014 to approve a nearly $10 million deal to help the casinos cover their payments to slot machine vendors.

A year later, a state panel recommended the Legislature pass a tax package valued at $46 million — a proposal that never came to fruition. Dover Downs has since recorded an annual operating loss twice and eliminated 72 positions.

A reversal in the state's own financial fortunes likely was the main reason this bill is headed for passage. Delaware went from closing a nearly $400 million budget gap last year to having $380 million in extra cash this year.

Reaching a tax cut for the casinos did not go smoothly, however.

Gov. John Carney's administration negotiated a tax break proposal valued at $20 million only after Sen. Harris McDowell, who chairs the Senate Finance Committee, vowed to move Bushweller's original bill.

The Carney-backed deal cleared the Senate in April, 17-3. But it stalled in the House after encountering resistance from Speaker Pete Schwartkopf, D-Rehoboth Beach, who sought to chop the cut in half.

His opposition to Carney's plan seemed to be reinforced by the addition of full sports betting at casinos earlier this month, thanks to a recent U.S. Supreme Court decision. The casinos have argued sports betting will not be a major moneymaker.

Schwartzkopf finally blinked Thursday by presenting a compromise that reduced the tax cut by $3.6 million next year and $3.2 million thereafter. That allowed the bill to reach the House floor on the second-to-last day of the legislative session.

"We were running out of time," Schwartzkopf said, noting the full tax cut proposal likely had enough votes to pass.

"They got the money they think they need to make their businesses solvent, keep all their employees and reinvest back into their businesses," he said. "And we got $3.6 million. You can provide a lot of services for $3.6 million."

The budget-writing Joint Finance Committee will likely reallocate that savings on Saturday, while the Senate is expected vote on the compromise bill before it recesses sometime in the early-morning hours on Sunday.

search_result.title: Delaware corporate tax hike moves forward
search_result.text:
The Delaware General Assembly appears ready to hike taxes and fees on big companies that incorporate in the state.

Legislation sponsored by both Democratic and Republican leaders would raise about $116 million through the corporate franchise tax and related fees. That would be a major first step towards fixing the state's nearly $400 million budget shortfall.

"This is a big piece of the revenue side," said Speaker of the House Pete Schwartzkopf, D-Rehoboth. "I'm going to be glad when we get this done."

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

But, even assuming the bill passes, the General Assembly still must find close to $300 million in other tax increases or spending cuts to create a balanced budget before July 1.

IN LEG HALL:The fight over reinstating the death penalty in Delaware

Gov. John Carney proposed the corporate tax increase in March, when he released his recommended budget for next fiscal year.

The plan would create a new, higher corporate franchise tax bracket for the largest companies. According to the Department of State, about 1,900 companies would pay the new top rate, $250,000 annually. The current maximum is $180,000 a year.

That bracket would apply to companies that have $750 million in either revenue or assets, but it would not apply to companies that have less than $250 million in one of those metrics.

So, for example, an internet-based company that makes $1 billion a year in sales but does not have assets worth $250 million would not pay the new top rate. But a company that has $755 million in revenue and $260 million in assets would pay the new rate.

"This is only the biggest of the biggest of the Fortune 500 companies we're talking about," said Schwartzkopf, who is lead sponsor of the bill.

If the legislation passes, the second highest rate also would see an upward move, and companies that fall into that category would pay $200,000 annually.

Companies would also pay more in late fees and to file records with the state. State officials say those increases account for inflation.

The corporate franchise is a central pillar of Delaware's economy — the state is famously home to more corporations than people. Corporate taxes and fees bring in more than a third of the revenue for state government's general fund budget.

Secretary of State Jeffrey Bullock does not believe the tax and fee increases will scare away businesses. The fundamental reasons Delaware is appealing as a place to incorporate is its consistent and world-renowned Chancery Court and a nimble state government that quickly reacts to changes in the business world, he argues.

"The franchise is as strong as it's ever been in Delaware," Bullock said, noting that the number of Fortune 500 companies incorporating here has reached record levels. "Do we want to be doing this every year? No. But as long as we're judicious about it and we don't go too far too fast, it will not cause us to lose business."

Delaware State Chamber of Commerce president Rich Heffron says nobody likes raising taxes, but he agrees this should not cause major problems. The corporate franchise was last increased eight years ago, he points out.

"You have to be worried about the long-term trend, and you can't do this too often," he said. "But they seem to be handling this responsibly."

Because the legislation raises taxes, it requires a three-fifths vote in each chamber. Schwartzkopf believes he has the votes, and the bi-partisan sponsor list suggests he is right.

Senate Minority Leader Gary Simpson, R-Milford, is a co-sponsor, and he thinks the bill will pass.

"I'm certainly not thrilled about it," said Simpson, the Senate's ranking Republican. "But if we're going to raise any tax, we might as well raise one that would not be harmful to our corporate image but would benefit the state."

Schwartzkopf hopes the legislation will pass the House by the end of this week. Legislators go on a two-week break next week, so the Senate would vote on it June 6-8, at the earliest.

If they follow Carney's lead, legislators would also raise the personal income tax and taxes on tobacco. But those ideas — particularly the income tax — have proven more controversial.

BACKGROUND:More on the debate over the income tax

Carney proposed increasing rates for every income tax bracket and eliminating itemized deductions. But some of his fellow Democrats want to create new, higher tax brackets, which would mean the wealthiest Delawareans would see bigger tax hikes.

Schwartzkopf would vote for creating new brackets. But he says there aren't enough votes to do so. Republicans and some Democrats dislike the idea of a higher top income tax rate, fearing it will scare away businesses.

The other question is whether the General Assembly will balance the budget with an equal balance of spending cuts and revenue increases. But some legislators think the state can find more places to shrink government before they turn to tax increases.

"The majority of our time has been talking about the cuts," Schwartzkopf said. "When we get to a place where we're happy with the amount of cuts, that's when the conversation will steer to revenue."

Still, Schwartzkopf says a deal will likely need to be struck on further taxes at some point.

"I don't think people want to do this with all cuts. That would have a major impact in our state," he said. "We're still working on it. We're still talking. We'll get there."

search_result.title: Republicans seek prevailing wage change in budget deal
search_result.text:
Republicans want to give counties, cities and schools a three-year exemption on the mandatory "prevailing wage" for government construction projects.

Republicans are trying the idea, which they have long pushed for, to the high-stakes negotiations over how to solve Delaware's $400 million budget problem. They argue it is a fair request to systemically reduce government spending at a time when Democrats are asking them to allow more tax increases.

BACKGROUND:An in-depth look at the budget showdown.

RELATED:Abortion is another white-hot debate in the General Assembly

"[Prevailing wage] is an outdated idea, and we can't afford to have it," said Sen. Greg Lavelle, R-Sharpley, and the Senate minority whip. "The governor says we need structural reforms, well, we're not going to get there just by raising taxes."

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

Some Democrats, however, accuse the Republicans of holding up the budget process in hopes of passing a policy for which they otherwise couldn't get the votes. They say the Republicans' proposal would lead to thousands of workers taking steep pay cuts.

"Our job should be to protect workers, not destroy the wages of workers," said Rep. Michael Mulrooney, D-Newark, and a longtime union official. "Why you would want to balance the budget on the backs of workers...it just befuddles me that they want to do that."

Mulrooney said the prevailing wage also protects small construction firms by preventing larger companies from undercutting them on price.

Prevailing wage is a minimum level of pay for workers on government contracts that is established by the Department of Labor. Different jobs have different prevailing wages, which are set by a survey of employers in similar fields.

The prevailing wage for a bricklayer in New Castle County, for example, is $51.99 an hour, while the wage for a truck driver in Kent County is $27.44. A laborer in Sussex County makes $43.60, while a New Castle County painter makes $46.72.

Debate over the prevailing wage would likely be intense in any circumstance, but it takes on huge significance now that it is tied into budget discussions.

Delaware faces a roughly $400 million budget deficit, but the General Assembly has only come to an agreement on about half the cuts and taxes necessary to fix that. Democrats and Republicans remain at an impasse over further tax increases, particularly the personal income tax.

The clock is ticking – state law requires them to pass a balanced budget by June 30.

Republicans have long argued the survey system is broken and that the prevailing wage is significantly higher than similar private sector workers. They point out that construction workers on government projects often earn noticeably more than teachers or nurses.

"Let's put it this way, you or I certainly wouldn't pay this rate to do work on our home," said Rep. Danny Short, R-Seaford, the House minority leader. "No private business would build at this rate."

Republicans point to a recent Sussex County project to build a new EMS station. County officials estimate the project cost 24 percent more because of the prevailing wage than it would have at market rates.

The GOP is offering two bills, sponsored by the party's leadership in each chamber, that would create a three-year exemption to the prevailing wage. One would be for county and municipal governments and the other would cover school districts.

The governments and districts would be required to prepare cost comparison reports that show how much they saved without having to follow prevailing wage.

"We are not demanding that we eliminate it, we just want to get these comparison reports and get some hard numbers," Short said. "Maybe it turns out that it wouldn't really save us that much, although I'm pretty sure that's not the case."

He added: "We're trying to be congenial here. We get that this is a real struggle for [Democrats]."

The bill would be controversial on its own, but its significance if ratcheted up because Republicans are using it as a bargaining chip in budget negotiations.

Delaware has a roughly $400 million budget shortfall. Gov. John Carney has proposed fixing the problem with about $200 million in new taxes and $200 million in spending cuts, what he calls a "balanced approach."

But legislators have only agreed to about $119 million in tax increases. Republicans allowed an increase in the corporate franchise tax because Democrats allowed the estate tax to be repealed.

The two parties have not been able to reach an agreement on further tax increases, however. Carney and Democratic leaders say an increase in the personal income tax is necessary for long-term budget stability, but Republicans have so far resisted.

Since tax increases require a three-fifths vote, Democrats need a handful of Republican votes.

GOP leaders have been saying for awhile that they wanted commitments to reducing spending if they were to support further tax increases but have previously been mum on specifics. The prevailing wage proposal appears to be part of their request.

Speaker of the House Pete Schwartzkopf, D-Rehoboth, does not think the prevailing wage should be part of the budget negotiations.

"Prevailing wage does not affect our budget one penny," Schwartzkopf said.

Schwartzkopf points out that construction projects fall in the "bond bill" that funds capital projects or the Transportation Trust Fund. Both of those are separate from the General Fund, which is where the $400 million problem lies.

But Republicans point out that legislators often add general fund cash to the bond bill in, and could do less of that if the bond bill saved money on labor costs.

And they say the state would save local governments and school districts money at a time when many in state government think they should be picking up greater responsibility for the state's costs.

Gov. John Carney opposes changes to the prevailing wage as part of a budget solution.

"Our budget negotiations need to focus on achieving a combination of new revenues and spending restraint that's necessary not only for this year but in the long term," spokesman Jonathan Starkey said.

Sen. Gary Simpson, R-Milford, said he thinks Carney needs to press harder on his own party to make responsible cuts. After all, they've agreed to less than half of the $200 million in cuts Carney proposed.

"I think the governor needs to get involved," Simpson said. "I'm tired of meeting with a recalcitrant Democratic leadership that just keeps asking us to pass tax increases."

Republicans have questioned Democrats' commitment to responsibly cutting spending after Democratic leaders told the Joint Finance Committee to halt its work even though it had only voted to cut about $80 million

Schwartzkopf says leaders have agreed to other cuts that don't require votes, like the decision to give zero general fund cash to the bond bill. He estimates Democrats have about $170 million in cuts ready to make.

He said the budget cannot pass unless more new revenue is added because Democrats — including possibly himself — would vote against a budget with almost $300 million in budget cuts.

"I'm still optimistic," Schwartzkopf said. "But we're running out of time."

search_result.title: Proposed Delaware income, alcohol tax increases draw criticism
search_result.text:
Critics of proposed increases to taxes on income, alcohol and cigarettes packed Legislative Hall on Wednesday to argue the hikes could hurt the state's small businesses and economy.

Legislative leaders said they didn't like asking for tax hikes, but said they were a necessary evil given that state government is still in a budget hole of hundreds of millions of dollars.

"I don't want you to sit here thinking that I'm liking what I'm doing. This is not fun," said Speaker of the House Pete Schwartzkopf, D-Rehoboth. "If we have to cut $300 million out of our budget, explaining this bill to my district will be easy compared to explaining to everybody else in the state what we did to their jobs, their services, their livelihoods."

BACKGROUND:Read details on the income tax proposal

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

THE BACKSTORY:Read about the state's budget plight

The House Revenue and Finance Committee approved three major bills to increase taxes on Tuesday.

The first is the Democrats' plan to raise income taxes. The legislation would create a new top tax bracket for people earning $150,000 or more, eliminate itemized deductions and increase tax rates for virtually all Delawareans.

Gov. John Carney and Democratic legislative leaders say that increase is crucial to a long-term budget solution because the income tax grows steadily with the economy. It would raise $68 million in the next fiscal year and $211 million in the next fiscal year after that.

Democratic leaders have not convinced Republicans to give them the handful of votes they need to pass the income tax increase.

Leaders of the nonprofit community voiced fears that eliminating the itemized deduction for charitable donations could hurt their fundraising.

"We're dependent on the individual donor to give, and it is a very tough environment out there to give," said Tyrone Jones, chief impact officer at the United Way of Delaware.

Many nonprofit leaders support the rest of the income tax bill because it would raise money that might help prevent cuts to their state funding.

Rep. Quinton Johnson, D-Middletown, said he didn't want to raise the tax but felt the General Assembly had little choice.

"We are at a point in time where these are mathematical decisions, not political decisions," Johnson said.

The tax that drew the most criticism Wednesday was a plan to raise taxes on beer, wine and spirits. So many distributors, brewery owners and liquor store owners flooded the basement hearing room that legislative staffers had to herd them into the cafeteria, where the meeting was shown on a television screen.

"Prices will go up. Of this, there is no doubt," said Jay Hibbard, vice president of the Distilled Spirits Council. "When prices go up, sales go down."

Schwartzkopf said he intends to file an amendment to lower the amount of the proposed increase from what was originally proposed.

Here are the new rates: on a six-pack of beer, from 9 cents to 15 cents; on 750 milliliters of wine, from 19 cents to 32 cents; on 750 milliliters of spirits, from 74 cents to 89 cents.

Representatives of several Delaware breweries, including Iron Hill and Dogfish Head, said the tax increase would harm a budding industry.

"This tax would directly, negatively affect my ability to expand, to hire more people," said Eric Williams, founder and owner of Mispillion River Brewing.

While the bill passed the committee, several lawmakers said they would likely not vote for the alcohol tax increase in the full House.

Rep. Bryon Short suggested the tax increase was not worth the amount it would raise. With the amendment, the bill would raise $5.2 million in the next fiscal year and $7.1 million in the year after that.

"I think this is nibbling around the edges and, respectfully, does not contribute meaningfully to the solution," Short said.

Schwartzkopf reiterated that he would prefer not to raise the tax.

"If we can get some kind of a bipartisan agreement to do a large amount with one bill, I'd be more than happy to do that," Schwartzkopf said, urging Republicans to support the income tax hike.

The committee also passed a proposal to raise increases on cigarettes, e-cigarettes and other tobacco products. It would bring in around $11.6 million.

David Eisenhour, owner of Delmarva Vapor Lounge, said the 5-cent new tax on "vaping" products would stop people from coming to Delaware to buy his products.

"I could tolerate a penny. I could stomach two pennies. But when you get up to 5 cents, you're just going to murder our business," said David Eisenhour, owner of Delmarva Vapor Lounge.

But some health advocacy groups have criticized legislators for making the tax increases too small. Gov. John Carney had proposed a $1 per pack increase on cigarettes, but the bill would increase it only 50 cents.

"With a one dollar per pack increase, Delaware had the opportunity to make a bold statement about our desire to address the leading preventable cause of death and disease in our state," said Jonathan Kirch, government relations director for the American Heart Association in Delaware, in a statement. "It is outrageous that some of our elected officials seem more concerned about keeping tobacco prices low than they are about keeping our youth from getting addicted to this deadly product. Compromising on public health is never the right answer."

search_result.title: Democrats propose tobacco, alcohol tax increases
search_result.text:
Democrats have unveiled plans to raise taxes on alcohol, cigarettes and "vaping" products as part of their solution to the state's $400 million budget quandary.

Combined, the proposals would raise $18.8 million for the next fiscal year. The increases would take effect in September.

"I can't imagine anybody's happy about a tax increase," said Speaker of the House Pete Schwartzkopf, D-Rehoboth. "But we've got to get more revenue to avoid some of the cuts we're talking about."

THE BACKSTORY:An in-depth look at the state's budget showdown

Here's how the alcohol taxes would increase:

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

The tax on a six-pack of beer would grow by 12 cents, to 21 cents.

The tax on a 750 ml bottle of wine would grow by 15 cents, to 34 cents.

The tax on a 750 ml bottle of spirits would grow by 15 cents, to 89 cents.

The alcohol tax is based on volume, not value. So the tax on Glenlivet scotch is the same as Captain Morgan rum, and the tax on Dogfish Head beer is the same as the tax on Pabst Blue Ribbon.

Here's how the cigarette taxes would increase:

The tax on cigarettes would increase by 50 cents per 20-cigarette pack, to $2.10.

A new five-cent tax would be imposed on each millimeter of fluid for e-cigarettes or "vapes."

The tax on moist snuff would grow from 54 cents to 92 cents

The tax on all other tobacco products would grow from 15 percent of the wholesale price to 30 percent

If passed, legislators would take a different approach than Gov. John Carney did in his budget proposal. Carney did not ask for an alcohol tax increase, but asked for a larger cigarette tax increase of $1 per pack.

"I thought that was excessive," said Sen. Gary Simpson, R-Milford and the Senate Minority Leader.

Carney has said he will accept tweaks to his proposals if they help legislators reach a larger balanced budget deal.

Legislative leaders in both parties believe the taxes can pass as part of the compromises over the state budget. Schwartzkopf said he intends to have the bill brought up in committee on Wednesday and, if it passes there, voted on in the House on Thursday.

RELATED:Read about the Democrats' income tax proposal

RELATED:The General Assembly recently hiked corporate taxes

"I think we'll come to a resolution on those two taxes," said Simpson.

Schwartzkopf and Simpson both point out that the alcohol tax hasn't been increased since 1990. In fact, taxes on spirits were actually reduced in 1997.

Still, alcohol producers, distributors and sellers are anxious about taxes increasing.

"There would not only be an immediate short time impact on the bottom line of our brewers, some of whom are struggling to make ends meet, but it would particularly affect new brewers coming into the state," said John Klein, president of the Delaware Brewers Guild, which represents 18 breweries in the state.

Klein, who works for Dogfish Head, points out that the tax on a barrel of beer will go from $4.85 to $11.46, which he called a "huge" increase. He said most brewers and sellers won't have any choice but to pass the cost onto the consumer and increase prices.

"I like to think that Delaware's a business-friendly state, especially a small business state," he said. "Keeping taxes lower is the path we should continue down."

Klein said the increase would make Delaware's alcohol tax much higher than neighboring states. But lawmakers argue that Delaware has zero sales tax, so the total burden is still low.

Smokers, vapers and stores that sell cigarettes won't be happy about the additional tax, but some medical groups — like the American Lung Association and American Heart Association — back legislators' efforts. They supported even higher rates.

"Tobacco is the number one cause of preventable death in Delaware and nationwide," stated the IMPACT Delaware Tobacco Prevention Coalition, a group of health and public advocacy groups, in a letter to The News Journal. "This fact alone is sobering and should make the case for legislators in this state and across the nation to take appropriate action to curtail tobacco use."

Lawmakers have already signed off on increasing corporate taxes by more than $116 million. If the tobacco and alcohol taxes pass, they will have about $134 million.

Despite these agreements, the burning question in Legislative Hall remains unanswered: will legislators raise personal income taxes?

Gov. Carney and his fellow Democrats believe the income tax is stable and grows with the economy, so raising it is a vital part of a long-term budget solution. Yet Republicans say they won't provide the votes necessary to pass it unless Democrats consider some of their ideas for spending reform, like a three-year elimination of the prevailing wage.

Lawmakers have until June 30 to strike a deal.

"We're still at a standstill on that issue," Simpson said of the income tax. "I think my caucus, and I've heard the same thing from the House Republicans, we're not willing to budget without getting a meaningful move on prevailing wage."

Schwartzkopf said he is hopeful that negotiations on the budget can come to a head next week after the last meeting of the Delaware Economic and Financial Advisory Council, a panel of economists and state officials that estimates how much the state will have to spend.

"My hope is that, Tuesday, we'll have a different tenor of the discussion," Schwartzkopf said. "We still have time. We have 7 legislative days, and a lot can happen in 7 days."
